text:
```kelly_fraction = true_probability - (1 - true_probability) / (odds - 1)
if kelly_fraction > 0:
    stake = 0.5 * kelly_fraction * bankroll_size
    place_bet(stake, odds)```
You’re literally guaranteed to make money this way!

text: Regarding the first point, rather than having a single true probability where you eg add/subtract X% to derive the prices you will lay/back at, if you have an interval then the endpoints directly give you these and if you have a distribution you can eg take the 2.5% and 97.5% quantiles. This allows, for example, for you to have tighter margin on one side if you are more confident about the lower bound than the upper bound

elements.text: Regarding the first point, rather than having a single true probability where you eg add/subtract X% to derive the prices you will lay/back at, if you have an interval then the endpoints directly give you these and if you have a distribution you can eg take the 2.5% and 97.5% quantiles. This allows, for example, for you to have tighter margin on one side if you are more confident about the lower bound than the upper bound

text: For market implied probabilities typically you take inverse odds divided by the overround or maybe the midpoint of the back and lay. But really the market is giving you an interval: the true price lies somewhere between the inverse of the back and lay

elements.text: For market implied probabilities typically you take inverse odds divided by the overround or maybe the midpoint of the back and lay. But really the market is giving you an interval: the true price lies somewhere between the inverse of the back and lay

text: This is what I used to do with logistic regression models - use the SE given to get a rough CI around the point estimates.

elements.text: This is what I used to do with logistic regression models - use the SE given to get a rough CI around the point estimates.

text: One way you can take advantage of this would be if you are trying to fit a model to the implied probabilities, don’t try to find the parameters that give the closest probabilities to the point estimates but the ones where all probabilities fit within the intervals

elements.text: One way you can take advantage of this would be if you are trying to fit a model to the implied probabilities, don’t try to find the parameters that give the closest probabilities to the point estimates but the ones where all probabilities fit within the intervals

text: If I understand correctly what <@UBS7QANF3> alludes to is more akin to Bayesian inference rather than standard inference, where either analytically or by simulation, you have an understanding of how certain is your estimate of that probability. The more certain you are, the more you can trust your Kelly, for example (scaling the 0.5 or understanding the odds are 'almost unreal'). Which makes a lot of sense to me. Did I understand correctly?

alludes to is more akin to Bayesian inference rather than standard inference, where either analytically or by simulation, you have an understanding of how certain is your estimate of that probability. text: Bayesian you would get a distribution rather than the frequentist point estimates. But other stuff that generates a point estimate and a SE is "usually" going to be normally distributed in the CI sense. I am not speaking for <@UBS7QANF3> here this is just based off my own (outdated) days of modelling and basics of the premise of Bayesian versus Frequentist statistics.

text: I recall from logistic regression with logit link that because of the simple formula for logit there is a similar formula to map upper and lower confidence intervals for your modelled probability. This is what I used to use to give myself a "cushion" around the estimates. I am certain my model worked mainly because the bookies prices were so shite back in the mid to late 2000's rather than any modelling skill on my part. After all, it only used public data scraped from yahoo sports. Typing this makes me realise how long ago this was.....

text:
Fit an efficient market to find value in an inefficient market. Two examples:

1. Statistical arbitrage e.g win versus place
2. Use starting prices to fit a model to identify value in running

Use starting prices to fit a model to identify value in running

text: Pretty fascinating. My approach to generating fair value without involving the market seems to be fine in football, but always struggled with horses. Maybe also because it's difficult to tell a classifier that even though this horse is labelled as a loser, it came close to second so it could have very easily won. Regressing against some market-obtained values seems like a better way to do it indeed

elements.text: Pretty fascinating. My approach to generating fair value without involving the market seems to be fine in football, but always struggled with horses. Maybe also because it's difficult to tell a classifier that even though this horse is labelled as a loser, it came close to second so it could have very easily won. Regressing against some market-obtained values seems like a better way to do it indeed

text: Example: fitting your model to BSP gives you the distribution of speeds of the horses. You use these distributions in running combined with each horse's distance to the finish line to calculate an in running probability. Then you compare that to the current prices to find value. You're not comparing the current prices to the BSP to find value

elements.text: Example: fitting your model to BSP gives you the distribution of speeds of the horses. You use these distributions in running combined with each horse's distance to the finish line to calculate an in running probability. Then you compare that to the current prices to find value. You're not comparing the current prices to the BSP to find value
